awd_titl_txt: Decadal and multi-decadal ocean memory in the eddying regime
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate predictions on decadal scales have proven elusive. On these time-scales, the natural chaotic variability of the climate system dominates over the more predictable trends due to anthropogenic climate forcing. The differences among coupled general circulation models results are discouraging, and point to a lack of convergence in spatial resolution and to inadequate physical parameterizations. The difficulty is compounded by the short duration of observational records of the climate system, particularly those of the ocean and cryospherewhich hinders robust statistical analysis on decadal time scales.

A leading candidate for pockets of predictability in selected regions resides in the memory intrinsic in the slow, almost adiabatic evolution of the ocean below the mixed layer. The periodic reemergence of oceanic temperature anomalies in winter is a potential source of predictability on scales longer than one year. In order for this mechanism to provide robust interaction with the atmosphere, ocean temperature anomalies must survive the seasonal cycling and the eddy stirring on isopycnals. It is conjectured that temperature perturbations on scales larger than the eddy size survive isopycnal eddy stirring. The threshold amplitude and duration (or persistence) of perturbation that can withstand the seasonal cycling must be determined.

Intellectual Merit: This project will identify the regions in the Atlantic Ocean that can enhance decadal predictability in the extra-tropics. The focus on adiabatic subsurface flow in the eddying regime will complement the traditional approach of studying diffusive, highly damped oceanic dynamics, and will identify the most robust oceanic physical processes for prediction at decadal scales. The Atlantic Ocean is chosen because in this region the natural time scales are decadal, through the wind-gyres dynamics, and multi-decadal, through the pole-to-pole overturning circulation. It is essential to work in the eddying regime, because mesoscale eddies determine the sub-thermocline oceanic stratification and thus the oceanic heat transport. Furthermore, at high resolution, damping is reduced allowing large regional gradients and longer duration of influence: both are necessary elements for robust atmospheric imprinting. The approach is to use several ocean models spanning a range of complexities: coarse resolution forward and adjoint models both with parameterized baroclinic eddies, and a model at eddy-resolution.

Broader Impacts: The economical and social benefits of climate information for periods longer than a season and regions beyond the tropics cannot be overstated. Mid- and high-latitude ocean processes have the potential to provide skill to decadal forecasts, and they are the focus of this proposal. A graduate student and an early-career scientist will enrich their knowledge in physical oceanography, climate dynamics and the scientific method, and be trained in mathematics, numerical modeling and modern scientific computations. A middle and high school teacher workshop will contribute to informing the new generation of citizens on the achievements, limitations and future prospects of climate science.

por.por_cntn:
Water has the capacity to store much more heat than air. This means that the ocean provides memory to the climate system by storing large amounts of heat for long times and slowly releasing it to the atmosphere. It may be possible to use this memory to extend predictions of regional climate over several years by knowing the state of the ocean—particularly its temperature and currents in the top few hundreds meters. On the other hand, the ocean is subject to spontaneous internal variability on time scales ranging from seasons to centuries. Whether this variability helps or hinders climate forecasts depends on the nature of the variability. Rapid or random variability limits the ability to predict the future by obscuring the response of the ocean to atmospheric changes. In contrast, regular or repeating modes of oceanic variability may enhance forecasts since knowledge of the phase of a particular mode allows one to predict its future evolution.

With this in mind, this project has studied the natural ocean variability on interannual time-scales, using an ocean model where the surface forcing—winds, air temperature, and precipitation—are specified to be what is observed over an average year, and then repeated over many years, each year the same as the previous one. With this synthetic forcing, any variability longer than a year is spontaneously generated by the ocean. 

We have discovered that an oscillation emerges with a period close to four years. This near-global oscillation is strongest in the South Indian Ocean, with expressions in the whole Atlantic Ocean, but not in the Pacific. We have also determined that the process responsible for this four-year oscillation is an instability of the model's Leeuwin Current—the narrow current that flows along Western Australia. Although the Leeuwin Current is narrow, large-scale waves are radiated in the interior of the Indian Ocean and in the Atlantic. A figure of the density anomaly at 300 m associated with this oscillation can be seen in the attached figure.

The spontaneous excitation of this oscillation obscures the evolution of perturbations started in the North Atlantic for times longer than six years after the beginning of the perturbations, but the oscillation itself is very predictable, once it starts.

The project also uncovered some fundamental geometrical factors that enable the Atlantic ocean to be saltier than the Pacific. This difference in salinity is critical in localizing the mid-depth overturning in the Atlantic rather than the Pacific. One important geometrical characteristic is that the eastern boundary of the Atlantic ocean terminates at a subtropical latitude (the tip of South Africa) while the eastern boundary of the Pacific terminates at a subpolar latitude (the tip of South America). This arrangement favors the interbasin exchange to occur south of Africa, rather than through Drake Passage, enabling a flow of warm-salty upper-ocean water from the Indian to the Atlantic, rather than a flow of cold-fresh upper-ocean water from the Pacific to the Atlantic. The second important geometrical factor is the narrow east-west extent of the Atlantic relative to the Pacific. The Atlantic's narrow width allows the northward transport of upper salty waters associated with the mid-depth overturning to prevail over the southward transport of fresh water associated with the wind-driven subpolar gyre. The opposite is true in the wide Pacific. The net result is that the narrow Atlantic is saltier than the wide Pacific at the northern end of the basins.

Even within a single basin, the interplay between freshwater forcing, ocean salinity, and the overturning circulation is complex. The overturning circulation currently carries salt from the subtropical “desert latitudes” into the northern subpolar Atlantic. This salt transport counteracts the effect of precipitation at high latitudes, making the source waters of the overturning circulation denser and more likely to sink. However, sufficiently large inputs of freshwater can overwhelm this salt transport and lead to a shutdown of the overturning circulation. Our experiments showed that, once ocean mixing is reduced to realistic levels, both the “shutdown” and “on” states of the overturning circulation coexist with large-amplitude thermohaline oscillations (fluctuations in the strength of the overturning) with periods of decades to hundreds of years. These oscillations tend to destabilize the “shutdown” state, causing the circulation to return to its modern “on” state. These results suggest that the likelihood of a permanent collapse of the overturning circulation may be overestimated by ocean models run with excessively large mixing rates.
